questions.stem: When should italics be used for emphasis?

options.label: Frequently, to make text more interesting
Sparingly, when other methods won't work

questions.rationale: Italics for emphasis should be used sparingly and only when other methods of emphasis won't achieve the desired effect.

questions.stem: Click on the inappropriate use of italics:
questions.text: The *very important* meeting will discuss *budget*, *staff*, and *policies*
questions.rationale: Overusing italics for emphasis weakens their effect. Use italics sparingly.

questions.stem: Which is the best way to emphasize a key point?

options.label: Structure your writing to give natural emphasis

questions.rationale: Good writing structure provides natural emphasis better than typographic devices.
Italicize titles of books, newspapers, magazines, movies, plays, and other major works.

questions.stem: Which titles should be in quotation marks, not italics? (Select all)
questions.rationale: Use quotation marks for parts of larger works: articles, chapters, short stories.

questions.stem: I read an article called _____ in the _Toronto Star_.
questions.rationale: Article titles go in quotation marks; newspaper names are italicized.

questions.stem: When should foreign words be italicized?
questions.rationale: Italicize foreign words that haven't been fully adopted into English.

questions.stem: Sort these words by whether they need italics:
questions.rationale: Common foreign terms don't need italics; uncommon ones do.

questions.stem: Which Latin phrase doesn't need italics?
questions.rationale: Common abbreviations like 'etc.' are so familiar they don't need italics.
